questions.text: The most serious complication that may occur during the internal podalic version for a transverse lie is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The internal podalic version is an obsolete procedure in modern obstetrics for singleton fetuses, but may be used for the second twin in transverse lie. The most severe complication associated with this manoeuvre is uterine rupture.

  • Definition: Internal podalic version involves reaching into the uterus to grasp a fetal foot and turn the fetus to a breech presentation.
  • Current Use: Reserved for delivery of a second twin in a transverse lie when other options fail.
  • Complications:
    • Uterine rupture (most serious and life-threatening)
    • Uterine atony
    • Cervical and vaginal trauma
  • Contraindications include: previous cesarean delivery, contracted pelvis, absent amniotic fluid, and obstructed labour.

Explanation of Other Options:

Uterine atony (Option B): This can occur due to uterine manipulation, but is not the most serious or specific complication.

Cervical laceration (Option C): May occur during delivery, especially if the version is forceful or rapid, but is less severe than uterine rupture.

Vaginal ulceration (Option D): Not typically associated with the internal version; rare and unrelated.

choices.text: Reversion to the original position immediately by external version

questions.text: On performing an external cephalic version at 37 weeks for a breech presentation, transient fetal bradycardia is noted. What should be the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Transient fetal bradycardia during ECV is a recognised complication, usually due to transient cord compression or vagal stimulation. Reversion to the original lie is the first step if bradycardia persists beyond 10 minutes.

  • External Cephalic Version (ECV) is used to convert breech/transverse lie to cephalic near term.
  • It is ideally done after 36-37 weeks in a singleton fetus with normal amniotic fluid and reassuring fetal well-being.
  • Tocolytics such as Terbutaline 0.25 mg SC or Isoxsuprine IV are given before the procedure.
  • Ultrasound confirms lie, placental position, and AFI.
  • Pre- and post-procedure NSTs are mandatory.
  • Transient bradycardia is usually benign and resolves within 10 minutes.
  • Persistent bradycardia → suspect cord entanglement → revert to the original position.
  • If distress persists after reversion → emergency cesarean section is warranted.
  • A maximum of two attempts are allowed (one retry may be done the next day).

Summary Table: Management of Fetal Bradycardia after ECV

Explanation of Other Options:

Internal podalic version (Option B): Reserved for the second twin in a transverse lie; contraindicated in singleton term pregnancy.

Cesarean section (Option C): Not immediate unless fetal distress persists after reversion.

Rupture of membranes (Option D): Not indicated in this scenario and may complicate reversion or ECV attempts.

Explanation:

Vacuum extraction is contraindicated in cases of prematurity due to the increased risk of fetal scalp and intracranial injuries, including subgaleal haemorrhage and intraventricular haemorrhage, as the neonatal skull is more fragile in preterm infants.

It is also contraindicated in certain malpresentations like brow or face presentations, and when adequate maternal effort or anaesthesia cannot be ensured.

  • Gestational age <34 weeks is a strict contraindication.
  • The scalp may not tolerate vacuum-induced negative pressure, increasing the risk of trauma.
  • Alternative methods, like cesarean section, are preferred in premature infants.

Summary Table: Indications and Contraindications of Vacuum Extraction

Explanation of Other Options:

Brow presentation (Option B): Contraindicated for vacuum; brow lies between flexed (vertex) and extended (face) presentation; vacuum application is not feasible.

Fetal distress (Option C): Relative contraindication if delivery is not imminent; vacuum can be used if birth is anticipated within 15 minutes.

Cephalic presentation (Option D): Not a contraindication; vacuum is typically used in cephalic/vertex presentation when the head is engaged and no CPD.

choices.text: Can be used in a nondilated cervix
Can be used in an incompletely dilated cervix
Applied 3 cm posterior to anterior fontanel

questions.text: True about vacuum extraction of the fetus:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vacuum extraction (ventouse) may be used when the cervix is not fully dilated, provided it is at least 6 cm dilated. Thus, a vacuum can be used in an incompletely dilated cervix, but not in a nondilated cervix.

  • Vacuum is contraindicated in non-cephalic presentations (e.g., face, brow).
  • Proper cup placement is critical for success and should be applied over the flexion point, which is approximately 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, not posterior to the anterior fontanelle.
  • Incorrect cup placement (e.g., anterior placement near the anterior fontanelle) can cause cervical spine extension and failed traction.

Summary Table: Vacuum Extraction Key Points

Explanation of Other Options:

Can be used in nondilated cervix (Option A): Incorrect; at least 6 cm dilation is necessary before application.

Used in face presentation (Option C): Incorrect; vacuum is contraindicated in face presentations due to the risk of facial trauma and failure of traction.

Applied 3 cm posterior to anterior fontanel (Option D): Incorrect; correct site is 3 cm anterior to posterior fontanelle (not posterior to anterior).

questions.text: In heart disease, prophylactic forceps are applied at the head station of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prophylactic forceps are used in patients with maternal cardiac disease to shorten the second stage of labour and reduce the stress of maternal pushing.

Low forceps application is appropriate when the fetal head is engaged and the station is at or below +2 but not yet on the pelvic floor.

  • In cardiac conditions, low forceps (station +2) are preferred to reduce maternal exertion and prevent cardiovascular decompensation.
  • Outlet forceps require the fetal scalp to be visible at the introitus and the fetal head to be on the pelvic floor (station +3 or more).
  • Applying forceps at a higher station (e.g., 0 or -1) increases maternal and fetal risk and is contraindicated in such settings.

Explanation of Other Options:

-1 (Option A): The Head is above the ischial spines-forceps at this level carries a higher risk; contraindicated.

+1 (Option B): Still above low forceps threshold; not recommended in maternal heart disease.

0 (Option C): Head at ischial spines (engaged); not ideal for low forceps in cardiac disease.

questions.text: Forceps delivery is done in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Forceps delivery is contraindicated in mento posterior face presentation because the fetal chin is directed posteriorly, preventing engagement. Rotation to the mentoanterior is necessary before forceps can be applied.

  • In a mento posterior presentation, spontaneous vaginal delivery is not feasible unless anterior rotation occurs. Otherwise, a cesarean is indicated.
  • In deep transverse arrest, forceps or vacuum may be used if CPD is ruled out; Kielland forceps may be used for rotation.
  • Forceps are commonly applied for after-coming head of breech, typically using Piper forceps.
  • In maternal heart disease, prophylactic forceps may be used to shorten the second stage and reduce maternal exertion.

choices.text: Vacuum requires more clinical skills than forceps
Vacuum is preferred more in HIV patients than forceps
Forceps is more associated with fetal facial injury
Vacuum has a higher chance of the formation of cephalhematoma

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding forceps and vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery generally requires less technical skill compared to forceps application. Forceps delivery involves blade application, rotational alignment, and traction, demanding greater operator expertise and anatomical precision.

Additional key differences between forceps and vacuum delivery:

  • Vacuum is preferred in HIV-positive mothers (Option B) because it causes fewer fetal scalp lacerations, reducing vertical transmission risk.
  • Forceps deliveries are more associated with fetal facial injuries, such as facial nerve palsy or bruising (Option C).
  • Cephalhematoma is more common with vacuum due to negative suction pressure causing subperiosteal haemorrhage (Option D).

choices.text: Allows widening of the birth canal
Can be either midline or mediolateral
Involvement of the anal sphincter is classified 3rd-4th degree perineal tear
Midline episiotomies bleed less, are easier to repair and heal more quickly

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for episiotomies except:
questions.solution:
Episiotomy is defined as a surgical incision made over the perineum and vulva during delivery to increase the diameter of the vulval outlet (and not the whole of the birth canal) during childbirth and to prevent perineal tears. Thus, episiotomy is a surgically given perineal tear of the second degree.

Types of Episiotomy:

  • Median
  • Mediolateral
  • Lateral
  • 'J' shaped

Extra Edge: Structures cut in Mediolateral episiotomy (Very Important)

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of the levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of the pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Can be either midline or mediolateral (Option B): These are the two common types practised clinically.

Involvement of the anal sphincter is classified as 3rd-4th-degree perineal tear (Option C): Correct classification.

Midline episiotomies bleed less, are easier to repair and heal more quickly (Option D): True, but risk extension to the anus if not done carefully.

questions.text: The perineal tear should be repaired:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perineal tears, especially first- and second-degree, should be repaired immediately after delivery of the placenta, under good lighting and adequate analgesia. Immediate repair reduces the risk of infection, bleeding, and long-term complications such as pelvic floor dysfunction or incontinence.

  • First- and second-degree tears: Repaired similarly to episiotomy.
  • Third- and fourth-degree tears (Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injuries - OASIS):
    • Require layered repair.
    • The rectal mucosa and internal anal sphincter are repaired first.
    • The external anal sphincter is repaired either by the end-to-end or overlapping method.
    • Followed by vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and skin.
  • Delayed or secondary repair:
    • If repair is missed or wound breakdown occurs, it should be deferred for at least 8 weeks (after the infection is treated).

Explanation of Other Options:

24 hrs later (Option A): Incorrect; delay increases infection risk and is not standard of care.

48 hrs later (Option B): Incorrect; increases complications.

36 hrs later (Option C): Also incorrect; the standard is immediate repair.

questions.text: The following is always an indication for cesarean section, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cesarean section is not always required in cases of abruptio placentae. The mode of delivery depends on fetal viability and maternal condition.

  • Abruptio placentae: Cesarean is done only if there is fetal distress or rapid deterioration of the maternal condition. If the fetus is dead or of uncertain viability and labour is progressing, vaginal delivery is preferred.

Indications: Always Cesarean vs Conditional Cesarean

Explanation of Other Options:

Untreated stage Ib cervical cancer (Option B): Vaginal delivery is contraindicated; cesarean via classical incision is done.

Active primary genital herpes (Option C): Strong indication for cesarean to avoid neonatal herpes.

Type IV placenta previa (Option D): Always delivered by cesarean, irrespective of fetal viability.

Explanation:

Classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment. It is rarely performed today due to high rupture risk, but remains essential in specific clinical scenarios where lower-segment access is inadequate or contraindicated.

  • Carcinoma cervix (Ca cervix): Classical cesarean is indicated to avoid traversing the diseased cervix and for en bloc radical excision in cervical cancer.
  • The procedure is also considered when lower segment access is not feasible, e.g.:
    • Dense adhesions from previous surgery
    • Transverse lie with an unformed lower segment
    • Anterior placenta previa with suspicion of accreta
  • Classical cesarean is associated with a 4-9% risk of uterine rupture in subsequent pregnancies, as it involves the contractile upper segment.

Explanation of Other Options:

Kyphoscoliosis (Option B): Not an absolute indication for classical cesarean; delivery can often proceed with lower segment incision unless anatomical access is obstructed.

Previous 2 LSCS (Option C): Not an automatic indication for classical CS. Most repeat cesareans are safely done via the lower segment.

HSV infection (Option D): Cesarean is indicated if active lesions are present, but the classical approach is unnecessary.

questions.text: Vaginal birth after caesarean section (VBAC) is contraindicated in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Absence of prior vaginal birth is a relative contraindication - not an absolute one - for trial of labour after cesarean (TOLAC). Though prior vaginal delivery significantly improves VBAC success rates and reduces uterine rupture risk, the lack of it does not outright contraindicate TOLAC.

VBAC Contraindications (Absolute):

  • Previous classical cesarean section
  • Prior uterine rupture
  • Suspected CPD or contracted pelvis
  • Inability to perform emergency cesarean (logistical limitations)

VBAC Considerations (per ACOG):

  • One prior low-transverse CS
  • Clinically adequate pelvis
  • No other uterine scars or rupture
  • Immediate availability of emergency CS setup
  • Prior vaginal delivery improves success and safety, but its absence is not an absolute contraindication

Explanation of Other Options:

Previous classical section (Option A): Contraindicated due to high rupture risk with upper segment scar.

Suspected CPD (Option B): Not compatible with TOLAC; risk of failure and uterine rupture.

Previous uterine rupture (Option D): Absolute contraindication due to high re-rupture risk.

Reference:

  1. ACOG Guidelines (referenced in Williams)

questions.text: In a woman having a previous history of cesarean section, all of the following are acceptable indications for the trial of labour after cesarean (TOLAC/VBAC), except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

VBAC can be safely attempted in carefully selected women with one previous lower-segment cesarean section and no contraindications.

  • A clinically adequate pelvis is an essential prerequisite.
  • Midpelvic contraction, indicative of cephalopelvic disproportion, is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC/VBAC.
  • Occipito-posterior position is not a contraindication to VBAC. It may prolong labour but doesn't independently preclude a trial of labour. (Option A)
  • Fetal distress as an indication of previous CS is not a contraindication for VBAC, provided it's not recurrent and other criteria are met. (Option B)
  • Breech presentation as a previous indication generally carries a favourable prognosis for TOLAC, assuming cephalic presentation now. (Option C)
  • Mid pelvic contraction implies inadequate pelvis → absolute contraindication to VBAC.

questions.text: The best level of anaesthesia required for Lower Segment Caesarean Section (LSCS) is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ideal sensory level of anaesthesia required for cesarean section is up to the T4 dermatome, which corresponds to the nipple line. This level ensures complete anaesthesia of the uterus and peritoneum to avoid intraoperative pain during uterine manipulation and traction.

  • Spinal anaesthesia is most commonly used for elective LSCS due to its rapid onset and high success rate.
  • For normal vaginal delivery or operative vaginal delivery, a sensory block up to T10-S1 is sufficient.
  • For cesarean delivery, the block must extend to T4, as higher sensory input from the peritoneum and uterus needs to be covered.

Spinal Anaesthesia Levels for Obstetric Procedures

Explanation of Other Options:

T8 (Option A): Inadequate for peritoneal traction during cesarean.

T10 (Option B): Adequate for vaginal delivery, not cesarean.

T6 (Option C): Close but still suboptimal for full surgical field anaesthesia.

choices.text: Removal of both fetus and placenta
Laparoscopic ligation of the umbilical cord
Closely follow until viability and then deliver by laparotomy

questions.text: You are called to the operating room. The general surgeons have operated on a woman to rule out appendicitis and find signs of an abdominal pregnancy with a 16-week fetus and placenta attached to the omentum. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
In cases of abdominal pregnancy where the placenta is attached to vital organs (like the bowel, bladder, or omentum), attempted removal of the placenta can lead to life-threatening haemorrhage. Therefore:

  • The recommended approach is the removal of the fetus only, leaving the placenta in situ.
  • The umbilical cord is tied and cut close to the placental insertion.
  • The placenta is left to undergo aseptic autolysis, and involution is monitored by β-hCG levels and ultrasound.

Explanation of Other Options:

Removal of both fetus and placenta (Option A): Dangerous if the placenta is on vital organs; risk of uncontrollable bleeding.

Laparoscopic ligation of umbilical cord (Option B): Not feasible at 16 weeks and not standard; open surgery preferred.

Closely follow until viability (Option D): Not recommended; abdominal pregnancy carries a high risk of rupture and maternal morbidity. Immediate laparotomy is standard.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for cesarean hysterectomy, except:
questions.solution:
Cesarean hysterectomy is the removal of the uterus during or immediately after a cesarean delivery. It is typically done to control life-threatening obstetric haemorrhage.

  • The most common indication is placenta accreta spectrum (PAS)
  • Other indications include uterine rupture and intractable uterine atony with uncontrolled postpartum haemorrhage.
  • Couvelaire uterus, despite appearing alarming, is not an indication of hysterectomy. It results from extravasation of blood into the uterine muscle during abruption placentae, but the uterus often regains function after delivery and bleeding control.

Couvelaire Uterus

Symphysiotomy is a surgical procedure in which the pubic symphysis is divided to enlarge the pelvic outlet. It is used in selected cases of obstructed labour when cesarean delivery is not feasible or is deemed risky.

  • Indicated primarily in outlet contraction, not in brim or cavity contraction.
  • Ideal scenario: isolated outlet contraction, vertex presentation, fetal heart sounds present, and established obstruction.
  • Procedure: Symphysis pubis is divided strictly in the midline down to the arcuate ligament.
  • Delivery follows via ventouse/forceps or spontaneous expulsion with liberal episiotomy.
  • Advantages: Permanent increase in pelvic outlet diameter; may benefit future deliveries.
  • Complications: Retropubic pain, pubic osteitis, stress incontinence, rarely VVF.

(Other options are ruled out)

questions.text: In classical caesarean section, more risk of rupture of the uterus in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Uterine rupture is classified into spontaneous rupture (due to non-obstructive or obstructive causes) and rupture of uterine scars.

  • Classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper segment of the uterus.
  • This region is contractile, highly vascular, and less quiescent compared to the lower segment → hence prone to rupture.
  • Rupture risk: 4-9%, may even occur before the onset of labour.
  • The most common site of rupture in classical cesarean section is the upper segment.
  • In contrast, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) ruptures typically occur in the lower uterine segment, usually anteriorly and transversely.

questions.text: All are seen with scar dehiscence, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maternal bradycardia is not a recognised feature of scar dehiscence or uterine rupture. It is not part of the typical clinical presentation.

Scar dehiscence is a type of incomplete uterine rupture where the myometrium is separated but the serosa (visceral peritoneum) remains intact, preventing communication with the peritoneal cavity.

  • It is often asymptomatic and found incidentally during a cesarean section.
  • Fetal bradycardia is commonly seen and is the most frequent sign of uterine rupture, which may also occur in dehiscence.
  • Hematuria may occur if the bladder is involved, especially in cases with adhesions from previous surgeries.
  • Vaginal bleeding can occur if there is disruption near the lower segment or cervix.

Comparison of Uterine Rupture vs. Scar Dehiscence:
